Will the European Commission or other EU institution net borrow more than 
50bn in 2027 AND will the Eurozone not collapse before 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The European Commission, or another body or institution representing the EU, will borrow more than 
50,000,000,000 capital (net) from markets, in 2018 prices, in the year 2027. Organizations created by separate treaties between EU countries, such as the European Stability Mechanism, do not count. The EIB and the EFSF are also excluded. The question specifies 2018 prices to be comparable with NGEU RRF programme, which also specifies 2018 prices. See Regulation establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility, Article 6. The question specifies net borrowing activity, as the intention is to ask if the EU will continue to issue new debt. The intention of "Commission or other institution" criteria is to cover changes to the EU internal organization that result in bonds continuing to be issued on behalf of the EU but not by the European Commission. AND b.) At no time between December 1, 2020, to January 1, 2030, does the European Central Bank (ECB) formally close, and the Euro remains the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the Eurozone collapse before 2030 or the European Commission or other EU institution net borrow more than €50bn in 2027?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if either of the following occurs:
1. At any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency. Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.
2. The European Commission, or other body or institution representing the EU, will borrow more than €50 000 000 000 capital (net) from markets, in 2018 prices, in the year 2027. Organizations created by separate treaties between EU countries, such the European Stability Mechanism, do not count. The EIB and the EFSF are also excluded. The question specifies 2018 prices to be comparable with NGEU RRF programme, which also specifies 2018 prices. See Regulation establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility, Article 6. The question specifies net borrowing activity, as the intention is to ask if EU will continue to issue new debt. The intention of "Commission or other institution" criteria is to cover changes to the EU internal organization that result bonds continuing to be issued in behalf of the EU but not by the European Commission.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the Unique Games Conjecture be proved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if Boaz Barak writes publicly (on Twitter, a blog, or elsewhere) that Elchanan Mossel has won the bet. It resolves negatively if he announces Subhash Khot has won. If there is no announcement by the resolve date, then it resolves positively if there is a peer reviewed paper that was originally uploaded to the ArXiv in 2030 which is accepted in a major mathematics journal or computer science conference by the resolve date. Else, it resolves negatively

Q_and_not_P.title: Will quantum-enhanced machine learning be demonstrated by 2040 AND the Unique Games Conjecture not be proved by 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following criteria are met:

1. A single quantum computer satisfies all of the following criteria at any point between January 1, 2022 to January 1, 2040:
- Unambiguously capable of quantum advantage on some possibly unrelated task
- Utilizing quantum effects for the purpose of enhancing machine learning; utilizing only the classical part of a quantum computer is not sufficient
- Capable of baseline machine learning; defined as exceeding performance of either:
  - 85% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet with or without additional training data
  - IMPALA on any subset of at least 10 Atari games from the ALE on 200M steps
  - BERT on any subset of at least 5 GLUE or SuperGLUE individual benchmarks
  - Any other benchmark for classical machine learning that is significantly and unambiguously more difficult than all 3 baselines above
The question can resolve based on a blog post, scientific paper, or other type of announcement from a credible source. In case of significant ambiguity, the question should default to waiting for independent replication before positive resolution.

2. The Unique Games Conjecture is not proved by 2030, which resolves positively if Boaz Barak writes publicly (on Twitter, a blog, or elsewhere) that Subhash Khot has won the bet, or it resolves negatively if he announces Elchanan Mossel has won. If there is no announcement by the resolve date, then it resolves positively if there is no peer-reviewed paper that was originally uploaded to the ArXiv in 2030 which is accepted in a major mathematics journal or computer science conference by the resolve date. Else, it resolves negatively.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the Unique Games Conjecture be proved by 2030 or quantum-enhanced machine learning be demonstrated by 2040?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Unique Games Conjecture:
This question resolves positively if Boaz Barak writes publicly (on Twitter, a blog, or elsewhere) that Elchanan Mossel has won the bet. It resolves negatively if he announces Subhash Khot has won. If there is no announcement by the resolve date, then it resolves positively if there is a peer reviewed paper that was originally uploaded to the ArXiv in 2030 which is accepted in a major mathematics journal or computer science conference by the resolve date. Else, it resolves negatively.

Resolution Criteria for Quantum-enhanced machine learning:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if a single quantum computer satisfies all of the following criteria at any point between January 1, 2022 to January 1, 2040:
- unambiguously capable of quantum advantage on some possibly unrelated task
- utilizing quantum effects for the purpose of enhancing machine learning; utilizing only classical part of a quantum computer is not sufficient
- capable of baseline machine learning; we will define baseline as exceeding performance of either:
  - 85% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet with or without additional training data
  - IMPALA on any subset of at least 10 Atari games from the ALE on 200M steps
  - BERT on any subset of at least 5 GLUE or SuperGLUE individual benchmarks
  - any other benchmark for classical machine learning that is significantly and unambiguously more difficult than all 3 baselines above
The question can resolve based on a blog post, scientific paper or other type of announcement from a credible source. In case of significant ambiguity the question should default to waiting for independent replication before positive resolution.

P.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't.
If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will transformer derived architectures accelerate progress in deep learning AND if human-level AI is developed, will World GDP not grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve as YES if by January 1, 2025 there are at least 5 papers which successfully used transformer derived architectures to find improved neural network architectures or architecture components. Each paper must either use the transformer model to generate code for the architecture or to generate a natural language description of the architecture. Each of these papers must be cited at least 100 times as indicated by the corresponding Google Scholar page. The architecture components considered must be described by the paper authors as improving on the state-of-the-art with respect to some benchmark of the authors' choosing. The 5 papers need not be particularly distinct. If they all describe similar architectural innovations, this question will still resolve positive. The definition of "Transformer derived" is as per Metaculus user Barnett's definition. In case of contention, a strawpoll will be taken on the subreddit /r/machinelearning.

Resolution Criteria for Q: If a machine passes the test in the referenced Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP does not grow by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it does. If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

The combined question will resolve YES only if both of the following are true: (a) The criteria for P are met by January 1, 2025, AND (b) The criteria for Q are met according to the conditions specified. It will resolve NO if either of the criteria for P or Q are not met. If Q resolves ambiguously, the combined question will also resolve ambiguously.

P_or_Q.title: Will either human-level artificial intelligence lead to a 30% growth in World GDP within 15 years of its development, or will transformer derived architectures accelerate progress in deep learning by 2025?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for human-level AI and World GDP growth: If a machine passes the test in the referenced Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't. If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for transformer derived architectures in deep learning: This question will resolve as YES if by January 1, 2025, there are at least 5 papers which successfully used transformer derived architectures to find improved neural network architectures or architecture components. Each paper must either use the transformer model to generate code for the architecture or to generate a natural language description of the architecture. Each of these papers must be cited at least 100 times as indicated by the corresponding Google Scholar page. The code and/or description produced by the transformer model need not be complete or bug-free. The architecture components considered must be described by the paper authors as improving on the state-of-the-art with respect to some benchmark of the authors' choosing. The 5 papers need not be particularly distinct. If they all describe similar architectural innovations, this question will still resolve positive. If there is any contention in the Metaculus comment section, a strawpoll will be taken on the subreddit /r/machinelearning asking if it is accurate to say that the model in question is a derivative of the transformer model from Vaswani et al. After one week, a majority vote indicates the answer, with a tie indicating the answer "Yes".

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

Q_and_not_P.title: Ragnarok and 2024 US Presidential Election: Will a global catastrophe due to human-made climate change or geoengineering occur before 2100, and will Donald Trump not be elected US President in 2024?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for the combined question:

For the first part (Ragnarok Question Series):
If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth's climate system? A global catastrophe is defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less. This question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs. The catastrophe must be due to the direct effects of climate change that are generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no global warming but otherwise similar to ours, or due to the effects of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks.

For the second part (2024 US Presidential Election):
This question will resolve as No for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and Yes for all other options. The winner is the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or is selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. The question may resolve as Yes for all listed options, and options may be added later. If there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

The combined question resolves YES if both of the following occur:
1. A global catastrophe due to human-made climate change or geoengineering occurs before 2100, as defined above.
2. Donald Trump is not elected US President in the 2024 election, as defined above.

The combined question resolves NO if either:
- No global catastrophe as defined occurs before 2100.
- Donald Trump is elected US President in the 2024 election.

The combined question resolves AMBIGUOUSLY if:
- No global catastrophe occurs before 2100 and there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Donald Trump be elected US President in 2024 or a global catastrophe occur due to human-made climate change or geoengineering before 2100?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Donald Trump wins the 2024 US presidential election, determined by the majority of votes in the Electoral College or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. This does not require the individual to win the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning, or to be officially inaugurated. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this part will resolve as Ambiguous. (b) A global catastrophe happens before 2100, principally due to human-made climate change or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system, leading to a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less. This catastrophe must be due to the direct effects of climate change or geoengineering. Resolves NO if neither of these events occur. Resolves Ambiguously if no global catastrophe occurs by 2100.

P.title: Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolves as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

Q_and_not_P.title: Will there be at least one fatality in Pakistan from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030 AND will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China not lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for Pakistan nuclear detonation fatality:
This sub-question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this sub-question will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this sub-question will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in Pakistan, at any point between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by e.g., fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorized nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

Resolution Criteria for US-China armed conflict deaths:
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2050, neither of the following occur:
- There are not at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
- There are not at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to not reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.

The combined question will resolve as YES only if both sub-questions resolve as YES according to their respective criteria. It will resolve as NO if either sub-question resolves as NO or if the first sub-question resolves as Ambiguous.

P_or_Q.title: Will either armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050, or will there be at least one fatality in Pakistan from a nuclear detonation by 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occur:
1. At any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, there are at least three credible government sources or news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causes a total of at least 100 deaths. These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
2. There is at least one offensive nuclear detonation anywhere on Earth between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030, and there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in Pakistan at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation. If no such detonation occurs, this part of the question resolves as Ambiguous.
This question will resolve as NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day

Q_and_not_P.title: Will a US Democratic President sign into law a $500 billion spending cut before 2029 AND the S&P 500 neither rise nor fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positive if both of the following occur: a.) before 2029, a Democratic US President signs into law a budget that provides for 500 billion dollars less in spending than the budget of the previous year, AND b.) before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 does not move by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s, or a US Democratic President sign into law a $500 billion spending cut before 2029?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question resolves positively if any of the following occur:
1. Before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day.
2. Before 2029, a Democratic US President signs into law a budget that provides for 500 billion dollars less in spending than the budget of the previous year.

P.title: Before 2030, will an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of this bet. If Mitchell Kapor wins, then this question will resolve as No.
Each Turing Test Session will consist of at least three Turing Test Trials. For each such Turing Test Trial, a set of Turing Test Interviews will take place, followed by voting by the Turing Test Judges as described below.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Judges.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Human Foils. The Turing Test Human Foils should not be known (either personally or by reputation) to the Turing Test Judges.
During the Turing Test Interviews (for each Turing Test Trial), each of the three Turing Test Judges will conduct online interviews of each of the four Turing Test Candidates (i.e., the Computer and the three Turing Test Human Foils) for two hours each for a total of eight hours of interviews conducted by each of the three Turing Test Judges (for a total of 24 hours of interviews).
The Turing Test Interviews will consist of online text messages sent back and forth as in a online "instant messaging" chat, as that concept is understood in the year 2001.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will the first AGI be developed by a publicly traded company that outperforms the global equities market by at least 1.5x in the prior 12-2 months AND will an AI not complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet before 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
a.) The first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, and the total return (including dividends) of the company's stock over the period from 12 months prior to the date when the AGI is publicly known to one month prior to that date is at least 1.5 times greater than the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists, over the same period. The date when the AGI is publicly known is determined by the Metaculus question referenced in the original question. 
b.) The Long Now Foundation declares Mitchell Kapor the winner of the Turing Test bet, indicating that an AI has not completed the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet before 2030. 
Resolves NO if either or both of the above do not occur. If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, the first part of the question resolves ambiguously. The Turing Test criteria are based on a set of interviews and judgments as described in the original question.

P_or_Q.title: Will either an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet before 2030, or will a publicly traded company that develops the first AGI perform at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for each part:

1. This question will resolve as Yes if the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of the bet regarding the Turing Test. The Turing Test involves multiple sessions and trials, with specific procedures for conducting interviews and judging by appointed human judges and foils. If Mitchell Kapor wins, then this question will resolve as No.

2. This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as a specific Metaculus question. If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves based on the performance of the company's stock compared to the FTSE Global All Cap Index or a similar index over the specified period. The stock's total return must be 1.5 times greater than the index for a positive resolution. If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.

The question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Japan respond with military forces?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from of the beginning of the Chinese invasion.
In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:
The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan.
At least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule.
Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count

Q_and_not_P.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050 AND if China does not invade Taiwan before 2035, will Japan not respond with military forces?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify. Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.

Resolution Criteria for Q: If China launches a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does not invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan does not respond with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the Chinese invasion.

The question will resolve as YES only if both of the following occur: (a) There is a deliberate nuclear detonation as an act of war by any nation between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050, AND (b) China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, and Japan does not respond with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the Chinese invasion. The question will resolve as NO if either (a) or (b) does not occur.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (1) Japan responds with military forces if China invades Taiwan before 2035, (2) a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for (1): If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the Chinese invasion. China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur: The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan, or at least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule. Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to assassinate Chinese nationals, will count.
Resolution Criteria for (2): This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify. Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.

P.title: Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, either of the following occur:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolves as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

Q_and_not_P.title: Will there be an armed conflict between Taiwan and the PRC causing at least 100 deaths AND no armed conflict between the US and the PRC causing at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:
1. At any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, there is an armed conflict between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) that results in a total of at least 100 deaths, as reported by at least three credible government sources or at least three credible news reports.
2. At any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, there is no armed conflict between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China (PRC) that results in a total of at least 100 deaths, as reported by at least three credible government sources or at least three credible news reports.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths for the first part and for multiple separate events to not reach a total of 100 deaths for the second part.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

P_or_Q.title: Will armed conflicts involving the United States and/or Taiwan with the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, any of the following occur:
1. There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
2. There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the United States and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
3. There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
4. There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

P.title: Will a non-state actor have acquired a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This may occur (for example) by sales, theft, or a state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. This will not include cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not sufficient to resolve this question positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

Q_and_not_P.title: Will there be active warfare between the United States and China before 2027 AND no non-state actor acquires a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for active warfare between the United States and China: This question resolves YES if, at some point between now and 31 December 2026, at least two credible news sources (e.g., the Australian Financial Review, the New York Times, the Washington Post, Reuters, Associated Press, etc.) report that the United States and China have exchanged fire, engaged in "kinetic conflict", fought a battle, fought a war or otherwise engaged in active warfare (and they are not talking metaphorically/about a "cold war").

Resolution Criteria for non-state actor acquiring a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030: This question resolves YES if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, no individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it. This includes scenarios such as no sales, no theft, and no state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. Additionally, cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon are not considered in this question. A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not relevant for this question to resolve positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.

This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins.

The question resolves YES only if both criteria are met: (a) there is no active warfare between the United States and China before 2027, and (b) no non-state actor acquires a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030. It resolves NO if either (a) there is active warfare between the United States and China before 2027, or (b) a non-state actor acquires a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a non-state actor acquire a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030, or will there be active warfare between the United States and China before 2027?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Between the opening of this question and 2030-01-01, an individual or group not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon originally developed by a state, in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (excluding cases of independent development by non-state actors, acquisition of highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material alone, or dirty bombs). This may occur through sales, theft, or a state losing control of the weapon. Resolution will be based on official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In case of significant disagreement or ambiguity, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins. (b) At some point between now and 31 December 2026, at least two credible news sources report that the United States and China have exchanged fire, engaged in kinetic conflict, fought a battle, fought a war, or otherwise engaged in active warfare (not metaphorically or referring to a "cold war"). Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a China-Russia war by 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a China-Russia war is defined as the China and Russia collectively suffering at least 1000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the China and an ally of Russia or between Russia and an ally of the China will not count towards positive resolution.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.
See also
Will there be a deadly clash involving gunfire or explosives between Russia and China before 2024?
Will there be a US-China war by 2035?
[Will there be a China-India war by 2035?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8363/chin…

Q_and_not_P.title: Conditional on New START being renewed or replaced after February 2026, will there be both a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 AND no China-Russia war by 2035?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there is an agreement after 2026 that both US and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START. No attempt will be made to determine whether the renewed or replacement treaty actually has very similar terms to New START.

The question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. The condition of New START being renewed or replaced after February 2026 is met, AND there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035, defined as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory. A state (US or Russia) will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if either:
(a) The state openly admits such responsibility (in a statement made by the President, Prime Minister, Minister/Secretary of Defense, the US Ambassador to Russia (or vice versa), a top military executive or a similarly important official)
(b) Credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible
(c) There are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it.
If the state changes its claims (e.g. first admitting responsibility for the attack and then denying it), priority will be given to independent reports.

2. There is not a China-Russia war by 2035, defined as China and Russia collectively suffering at least 1000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources.

The question resolves NO if either of the conditions is not met. If the condition of New START being renewed or replaced after February 2026 is not met, the question resolves ambiguously.

For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations, but don't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions. Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.

In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. 
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack. 
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.

Battle related deaths are as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a China-Russia war occur by 2035 or a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US occur by 2035 conditional on New START being renewed or replaced after February 2026?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) A China-Russia war, defined as China and Russia collectively suffering at least 1000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between China and an ally of Russia or between Russia and an ally of China will not count towards positive resolution. (b) A nuclear exchange between Russia and the US, conditional on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026. This includes at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation by Russia on or over US territory, as defined by credible reports and not including detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

Q_and_not_P.title: Ragnarok Question Series: Will a global catastrophe before 2100 be due to nanotechnology failure-mode AND will Metaculus predict that AI does not pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of nanotechnology? A global catastrophe is defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years. The question resolves positively if a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, and resolves as ambiguous if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are defined as consecutive calendar years.

Resolution Criteria for Q: Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) fall below 5% in any 6-month period before 2040? This question resolves positively if either the Metaculus or community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

The combined question resolves YES if both: (a) a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% of the world population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, AND (b) either the Metaculus or community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040. It resolves NO if either of these conditions is not met.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040, or will a global catastrophe be due to nanotechnology failure-mode before 2100?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040. This will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. OR (b) A global catastrophe, defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less, occurs before 2100 and is principally due to the deployment of nanotechnology. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024[1]). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
[1] The reason for using 2030 rather than 2024 for this question is that the fatalities and discussion of them may occur on a several-year delay from the actual shortfall. It therefore seemed unwise to force this question to resolve by 2024, and hence best to make this part of the long-term rather than calibration tournament.

Q_and_not_P.title: Ragnarok and Agricultural Shortfall Series: Will a global catastrophe before 2100 due to human-made climate change or geoengineering not cause >400 million fatalities due to a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question combines two scenarios:

1. If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth's climate system? A global catastrophe is defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less. This question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs. The catastrophe must be due to the direct effects of climate change that are generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no global warming but otherwise similar to ours, or due to the effects of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks.

2. If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this not cause more than 400 million fatalities within 5 years of the end of the year in which the shortfall occurs? The question resolves ambiguously if there is no 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030. It resolves positively if less than or equal to three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.

The combined question resolves YES if both of the following occur:
a) A global catastrophe due to human-made climate change or geoengineering happens before 2100, causing a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years or less, AND
b) There is a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 that does not cause more than 400 million fatalities within 5 years of the end of the year in which the shortfall occurs.

The question resolves NO if either a global catastrophe does not occur before 2100, or if such a catastrophe does occur but is not due to human-made climate change or geoengineering, or if there is a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 that causes more than 400 million fatalities within 5 years of the end of the year in which the shortfall occurs.

For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.

P_or_Q.title: Will either a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause >400 million fatalities, or will a global catastrophe be due to human-made climate change or geoengineering?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the agricultural shortfall question:
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030. It resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. The question resolves positively if the above condition is met and at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.

Resolution Criteria for the global catastrophe question:
If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, this question resolves positively if it is principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system. The catastrophe must claim at least 10% of the world population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. This question resolves ambiguously if no such global catastrophe occurs.

The combined question resolves YES if either of the above conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: if there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2050, how many total detonations will there be by then? (over 1,000)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The sub-questions below will resolve as Yes if the number of offensive nuclear weapons detonations in total between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050 is greater than the respective threshold. If there is no fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, then all questions below will resolve as Ambiguous. That is, this question is conditional on at least one fatality from an offensive detonation occurring by 2050.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see fine print for definitions) of state or nonstate nuclear weapons, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Definitions of inadvertent, accidental and unauthorized detonations are taken from Barrett et al., 2013:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders. In a deliberate first attack, the attacking nation decides to attack based on accurate information about the state of affairs. In an inadvertent attack, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under attack and launches nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is offensive will be at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026 AND will there be 1,000 or fewer offensive nuclear detonations by 2050 with no fatalities from any offensive nuclear detonation?
Q_and_not_P.body:
This question will resolve positively if both of the following are true:

1. Afghanistan is used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026, which is determined by the occurrence of a terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people outside of Afghanistan, conducted by a member of the Afghan Taliban or any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban, as confirmed by credible media reports and determined by the United States federal government, NATO, or the European Union.

AND

2. The number of offensive nuclear weapons detonations between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2050, is less than or equal to 1,000, and there is no fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation in this time period. Offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorized detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons, excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

The question will resolve negatively if either of the above conditions is not met. For the first condition, an attack will be considered "against a NATO nation" if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g., embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals. For the second condition, if there is no fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation by 2050, the sub-question regarding the number of detonations will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (1) there are more than 1,000 offensive nuclear detonations by 2050, conditional on at least one fatality from an offensive detonation by then, or (2) Taliban-controlled Afghanistan is used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
P_or_Q.body:
(1) Resolves YES if the number of offensive nuclear weapons detonations between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2050, is greater than 1,000, provided there is at least one fatality from an offensive nuclear detonation in this time period. Resolves AMBIGUOUS if there is no fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation by 2050. Offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorized detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons, excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

(2) Resolves YES if both of the following are true based on credible media reports: a terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people has been conducted against a NATO nation by December 31, 2026, outside of Afghanistan, AND this terrorist attack was carried out by a member of the Afghan Taliban or a member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban. Resolves NO otherwise. An attack will be considered "against a NATO nation" if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g., embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. What counts as a "terrorist organization" will be determined by the US federal government, NATO, or the European Union. If NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution.

P.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if, at any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

Q_and_not_P.title: Will 1 bitcoin be worth $100,000 or more before 2025 AND will the Eurozone not collapse before 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: 
a.) One bitcoin is valued at $100,000 USD or greater at any time before January 1, 2025, according to credible press reports or a cryptocurrency exchange or trading platform. The valuation will be in nominal USD, not adjusted for inflation. 
AND 
b.) At any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) does not formally close, and the Euro remains the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, where being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.

The question will resolve as NO if either one of these conditions is not met.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the Eurozone collapse before 2030 or 1 bitcoin be worth $100,000 or more before 2025?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency. (b) One bitcoin is valued at $100,000 USD or greater at any time before January 1, 2025, according to credible press reports or a cryptocurrency exchange or trading platform. The valuation will be in nominal USD, not adjusted for inflation. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

Q_and_not_P.title: Will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100 AND will there not be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
Q_and_not_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) Before January 1 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as determined by the resolution criteria outlined by Nick Bostrom, with the resolution process involving both the community and Metaculus predictions or a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, AND b.) World output does not double in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, as determined by a credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars or other appropriately widely-accepted units. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur before their respective deadlines: (a) a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050, or (b) a fundamental change in the human condition before 2100?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for (a): This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, based on credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units). It resolves negatively otherwise, including if the related question about the sequence of doubling intervals resolves ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for (b): This question will resolve positively if, before January 1, 2100, the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, as defined by substantial discontinuities in social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality at the civilisational level. The resolution will be based on whether both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, or according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no, with 20% probability. If the question has not resolved by January 1, 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P.title: Will renewable energy contribute between 25% and 48% to global electricity production in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if renewable energy contributes between 25.00% and 48.00% (inclusive) to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments

Q_and_not_P.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident before 2030 AND will renewable energy contribute less than 25% or more than 48% to global electricity production in 2030?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: 

a.) An event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority (for example, any of the agencies featured on this list or this list), the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council.

b.) Renewable energy contributes less than 25.00% or more than 48.00% to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data. Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments.

The question will resolve as No if either or both of the conditions are not met.

P_or_Q.title: Will either renewable energy contribute between 25% and 48% to global electricity production in 2030, or will there be a major nuclear accident before 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: 
(a) Renewable energy contributes between 25.00% and 48.00% (inclusive) to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data. 
(b) An event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority (for example, any of the agencies featured on this list or this list), the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will countries possess a total of >20,000 nuclear weapons on December 31, 2029?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the total number of nuclear weapons (fission or thermonuclear) reported to be possessed across all countries on December 31, 2029 is greater than 20,000, according to the most recent FAS estimates available on December 31, 2029. This includes deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. It does not include weapons possessed by non-state actors.
Resolution criteria will come from FAS. If they cease publishing such numbers before resolution, resolution will come from the Arms Control Association or any other similar platform

Q_and_not_P.title: Conditional on New START not being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 AND will countries possess a total of "/u226420,000 nuclear weapons on December 31, 2029?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is not renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By the absence of replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there are no new agreements after 2026 that both US officials and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START. No attempt will be made to determine whether the renewed or replacement treaty actually does have very similar terms to New START.

The question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. The condition above is met and there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US between this question opening and 2035, defined here as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory. A state (US or Russia) will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if either:
(a) The state openly admits such responsibility (in a statement made by the President, Prime Minister, Minister/Secretary of Defense, the US Ambassador to Russia (or vice versa), a top military executive or a similarly important official)
(b) Credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible
(c) There are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it.
If the state changes its claims (e.g. first admitting responsibility for the attack and then denying it), priority will be given to independent reports.

2. The total number of nuclear weapons (fission or thermonuclear) reported to be possessed across all countries on December 31, 2029 is less than or equal to 20,000, according to the most recent FAS estimates available on December 31, 2029. This includes deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. It does not include weapons possessed by non-state actors.

For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions), but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions.

Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory.

Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.

In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. "/u201cIn an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack"/u201d (Barrett et al., 2013). "/u201cIn an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders"/u201d (Barrett et al., 2013).

Resolution criteria for the number of nuclear weapons will come from FAS. If they cease publishing such numbers before resolution, resolution will come from the Arms Control Association or any other similar platform.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) countries possess a total of >20,000 nuclear weapons on December 31, 2029, or (b) conditional on New START not being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for (a): This question will resolve as Yes if the total number of nuclear weapons (fission or thermonuclear) reported to be possessed across all countries on December 31, 2029 is greater than 20,000, according to the most recent FAS estimates available on December 31, 2029. This includes deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. It does not include weapons possessed by non-state actors. Resolution criteria will come from FAS. If they cease publishing such numbers before resolution, resolution will come from the Arms Control Association or any other similar platform.

Resolution Criteria for (b): This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is not renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By the absence of replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there are no new agreements after 2026 that both US officials and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START.
